title: Graph of Polynomial - Multiplicity of Zeros

content.question: Which of the following statements gives the multiplicity of the zero at <math alttext="C"> <mi>C</mi> </math> with correct reasoning?

choices.label: <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math>, because the graph of the function intersects the <math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis once at <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math>.

<math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math>, because the quartic polynomial function has four zeros: exactly one at <math alttext="A"><mi>A</mi></math>, one at <math alttext="B"><mi>B</mi></math>, one at <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math>, and a non-real zero.

<math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, because the quartic polynomial function has three real zeros, one of which must have a multiplicity of <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, and the polynomial does not change signs at <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math>.
<math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, because <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math> is the second zero to the right of the origin, and there are more zeros to the right than to the left of the origin.

content.answer: <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, because the quartic polynomial function has three real zeros, one of which must have a multiplicity of <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, and the polynomial does not change signs at <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math>.

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Support conclusions or choices with a logical rationale or appropriate data.
